cards.title: Athletics / Galen Rupp and Alberto Salazar meet applause and scepticism in Eugene
cards.rawTitle: Galen Rupp and Alberto Salazar meet applause and scepticism in Eugene

item.title: Galen Rupp and Alberto Salazar meet applause and scepticism in Eugene
item.trailText: Galen Rupp won the 10,000m at the USA Track and Field championships before a supportive crowd but not everyone in Eugene was happy
item.standFirst: Rupp won the 10,000m at the USA Track and Field championships before a supportive crowd but not everyone there was happy
item.body:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been hard, I‚Äôm not going to lie,‚Äù whispered the elfin figure of Galen Rupp in a voice so tender it could have melted in the 92-degree heat. A sweaty cat‚Äôs cradle of arms and Dictaphones strained to get closer, but only those nearest heard the pledge that will be broadcast repeatedly if the smoke swirling around Rupp and his coach Alberto Salazar erupts into fire. ‚ÄúI believe in clean sport and I believe the truth will prevail.‚Äù

Moments earlier, Rupp ‚Äì a silver medallist at London 2012 and a training partner of Mo Farah ‚Äì had found his feet to win his seventh consecutive US 10,000m championships. Finding his voice took longer. But nervously, hesitantly, he rediscovered it.

‚ÄúThe people here are so great,‚Äù he said, when asked about the standing ovation he received after crossing the line. ‚ÄúThe support has been tremendous. I was obviously pleased to get another championship and to do it here in Eugene, it‚Äôs always special.‚Äù

Related: Mo Farah: ‚ÄòI want to make it clear ‚Äì I will continue working with Alberto Salazar‚Äô

This was Rupp‚Äôs first race since a BBC Panorama documentary accused him of stretching and snapping anti-doping rules. But back at Hayward Field, where he ran in college for Oregon, he was greeted as more of a homecoming hero than someone fighting to remove a stain against his name.

Not everyone was cheering. One coach, who did not want to be named, feared the allegations were ‚Äúthe tip of the iceberg‚Äù and said USA Track and Field had not done enough to investigate. Not that he was surprised. ‚ÄúLook around you at the billboards,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd ask yourself who sponsors this championship and Alberto?‚Äù

Along the back straight there was a ready answer: a Nike.com/running sign was stapled to a USA Track and Field one.

Earlier, while other athletes warmed up in the practice field or had their muscles shaken into life on one of 28 massage tables, Rupp limbered up in private. Only when the final call for registrations crackled through on the public address system did he trot over to Salazar for final instructions. He then crossed himself twice before hugging the man he sees as a second father.

As Rupp went to the start, Salazar spoke for the first time since being accused of giving Rupp testosterone as a 16-year-old. He insisted he was ‚Äúfeeling good‚Äù despite the allegations swimming around him and ruled out legal action against the BBC and the US news website ProPublica, adding: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a vindictive person.‚Äù Despite Salazar‚Äôs upbeat words, his face told a different story. It looked tired and withdrawn. Apparently his blood pressure has been through the roof, which is not good for someone whose determination to be the greatest distance athlete of his age ‚Äì and arguably he was in the early 80s ‚Äì has left him with health problems. Remember, too, that he was clinically dead for 14 minutes after suffering a heart attack in 2007.

But Salazar lives and breathes every race that Rupp enters and watching his friend from the corporate hospitality area proved a sprightly pick-me-up. There were shouts of lap splits and encouragement, including a happy cry of ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go, Galen!‚Äù as his athlete powered clear to victory in the final kilometre.

It was an impressive performance, especially in conditions more like a steam room. But while Rupp was being photographed hugging his baby twins, the second-placed athlete, Ben True, was explaining why he had a very different ethos from his Nike Oregon Project rival.

‚ÄúAllegations are allegations and rumours are rumours but I am very much against doping,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúUse of therapeutic use exemptions, legal or not, are against the spirit of the sport. I don‚Äôt even take ibuprofen. I don‚Äôt drink recovery drinks. I have Gatorade maybe twice a year. I take acidophilus now and again and vitamin D in the winter. But I don‚Äôt even eat energy bars.‚Äù

Elsewhere on the first of four days at these US Trials, Dee Dee Trotter ‚Äì the 400m bronze medallist at London 2012 and founder of Test Me I‚Äôm Clean, which promotes drug-free sport ‚Äì called for a renewed push to stop people cheating or playing the system.

‚ÄúI think drugs in the sport are devastating,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a tragedy for the hardworking athletes like myself, I consider it to be similar to crime. When you cheat you‚Äôre taking something from the person behind you.‚Äù

When asked if sport was winning the fight, her answer brought to mind an unending tango between right and wrong, testers and cheats. ‚ÄúI think drugs in the sport are continuing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou think we‚Äôre getting better then we take two steps forward and two steps back.‚Äù

Meanwhile, in the mixed zone interview area, Rupp had moved from the press scrum to the TV cameras and was repeating a familiar mantra. ‚ÄúI believe in clean sport and I believe the truth will prevail.‚Äù

cards.title: Rugby league / Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders
cards.rawTitle: Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders

item.title: Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders
item.trailText: Star halfback Shaun Johnson again provided the spark as the Warriors consolidated their position in the top eight with a 30-8 win over Canberra in Auckland.
item.body:
Star halfback Shaun Johnson again provided the spark as the Warriors consolidated their position in the top eight with a 30-8 win over Canberra in Auckland.

It was Johnson, with his speed and step, who scored the try that gave the Warriors breathing space early in the second half of Saturday‚Äôs clash.

He then set up Tuimoala Lolohea for the winger‚Äôs second touchdown with a kick into the in-goal.

Winger Manu Vatuvei added the icing with four minutes to go by pulling in a lobbed pass from opposition halfback Sam Williams for his 11th try of the season.

It was also Vatuvei‚Äôs 14th try in his past seven matches against Canberra.

The win is the Warriors‚Äô fifth in a row over the Raiders, who remain in the bottom half of the table ahead of a bye for both teams.

The home side dominated possession and produced plenty of offloads as they forced the Raiders to make more than 400 tackles for the second weekend in a row.

They followed-up their victory over Gold Coast with another controlled start.

They got their reward in the 11th minute when second-rower Bodene Thompson marked his 100th NRL match by busting the line to dot down.

Canberra had been starved of good field position but made their first incursion into the Warriors‚Äô 20-metre zone tell.

Second-rower Sia Solioala‚Äôs inside ball sent fullback Jack Wighton over in the 18th minute.

Jarrod Croker landed the conversion and then nudged the visitors ahead with a penalty.

The Warriors regained the lead on the half-hour, blockbusting centre Konrad Hurrell taking on three defenders before offloading to Lolohea to score.

Johnson added the extras, then a penalty after the half-time hooter, for a 14-8 lead.

The Raiders‚Äô defeat was compounded by injury, with winger Jordan Rapana limping off before half-time.

Former Newcastle centre Joseph Leilua, signed earlier in June, came off the bench to make his Raiders debut.

displayImages.altText: Bodene Thompson scores a try despite the attentions of Edrick Lee during the match between the New Zealand Warriors and the Canberra Raiders at Mt Smart Stadium on Saturday.

snap.title: Shaun Johnson sparks Warriors in victory over Raiders

cards.title: Snooker / Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
cards.rawTitle: Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match

item.title: Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan claims he was offered money to throw a snooker match
item.trailText: Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan has claimed he was offered money to throw a snooker match but turned it down as the risk was not worth taking
item.standFirst:
‚Ä¢ Five-times world champion says the risk is not worth taking
‚Ä¢ Stephen Lee‚Äôs 12-year ban has scared a lot of players, he adds
item.body:
Ronnie O‚ÄôSullivan, the five-times world snooker champion, has said he was offered money to throw a match but declined.

Speaking on The Clare Balding Show, which will air on BT Sport and BBC Two this week, O‚ÄôSullivan claimed other players did accept bribes in the past but said he believed the problem had been eradicated after Stephen Lee was banned for match-fixing.

O‚ÄôSullivan said: ‚ÄúI was offered money once to throw a game but I couldn‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs your sport, you love your sport. They smell it anyway. The risk is just not worth taking and I couldn‚Äôt live with myself if I got involved in that.‚Äù

In 2012 Lee was suspended on match-fixing charges and the former world No5 was subsequently handed a 12-year ban.

Related: Stephen Lee banned from snooker for 12 years for seven match-fixing charges

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôll go on in snooker any more because they really made an example of Stephen Lee,‚Äù O‚ÄôSullivan added. ‚ÄúThey banned him for 12 years and I think a lot of the guys that were at it, they‚Äôre thinking they wouldn‚Äôt be able to play snooker ever again.

‚ÄúSo I think it‚Äôs been stamped out of snooker now and if anyone was to do it, they know what the consequences are.‚Äù

Three weeks ago, the Irish amateur John Sutton was banned for six years after the sport‚Äôs world governing body found him guilty of match-fixing and misusing inside information.

The World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association said Sutton‚Äôs offences related to suspicious betting on his match against Scotland‚Äôs Jamie Burnett in the qualifying stages of the International Championship.

cards.title: US sports / Women's World Cup: USA beat China 1-0 to reach semi-finals ‚Äì as it happened
cards.rawTitle: Women's World Cup: USA beat China 1-0 to reach semi-finals ‚Äì as it happened

item.title: Women's World Cup: USA beat China 1-0 to reach semi-finals ‚Äì as it happened
item.trailText: Carli Lloyd scores early in the second half as USA beat China 1-0 to reach the last four of the Women‚Äôs World Cup, where they‚Äôll play Germany
item.standFirst:
Carli Lloyd scores early in the second half as USA beat China 1-0 to reach the last four of the Women‚Äôs World Cup, where they‚Äôll play Germany

  • Tweet @timmyhilleh or email tim.hill@theguardian.com

displayImages.altText: USA and China battle in Ottawa.

bodyImages.caption: China clear the danger. Photograph: Sean Kilpatrick/AP
Carli Lloyd leaps to head home. Photograph: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
bodyImages.credit: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
bodyImages.altText: Carli Lloyd leaps to head home.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Carli Lloyd leaps to head home.
bodyImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

bodyImages.caption: Alex Morgan goes for goal. Photograph: Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images
These guys support USA ‚Ä¶ Photograph: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
bodyImages.credit: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
bodyImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lars Baron - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

bodyImages.caption: ‚Ä¶ but China have followers too. Photograph: Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images
Claire Lavogez, who missed the final kick for France. Photograph: Ryan Remiorz/AP
bodyImages.altText: Claire Lavogez, who missed the final kick for France.
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Claire Lavogez, who missed the final kick for France.

blocks.body:
Tim will be here shortly. In the meantime, here‚Äôs Caitlin Murray on why USA have to improve:

For a team that has advanced into the final eight and remains a favorite to win, the tone about the USA‚Äôs performances from pundits covering the team and from personnel affiliated with the program has become increasingly negative.

Former player Michelle Akers, who won the Golden Boot in 1991 when the USA won the Women‚Äôs World Cup, was especially blunt in her criticism after the USA‚Äôs 2-0 win over Colombia. Akers said of Ellis: ‚ÄúIf she is pleased with the way we played tonight, then what the hell is she doing coaching our US team?‚Äù

Related: USA face China for a last-four spot ‚Äì and if they don't improve, they're going home
Hi! Right then, let‚Äôs play some soccer. No contrived preamble tonight ‚Äìlet‚Äôs just get down to brass tacks: kick-off is 7.30pm ET, and I can‚Äôt wait. Ottawa‚Äôs ready!

blocks.title: Germany into semi-finals
blocks.body: Germany have just beaten France in Montreal, on penalty kicks, in the most heartbreaking fashion. Poor Claire Lavogez ‚Äì she took the final kick, Nadine Angerer saved, and the look on Lavogez‚Äôs face. So sad! Great game, that was: 1-1 after extra time, but France didn‚Äôt deserve to go out.

By the way, you must check out Gaetane Thiney‚Äôs miss, with about five minutes to go in extra time. France worked it so nicely down the right, and Thiney was completely unmarked at the far post ‚Ä¶ and missed! Looker looker:
The lineups are in:

So Kelley O‚ÄôHara starts for USA ‚Äì and no Abby Wambach, who starts from the bench. Megan Rapinoe and Lauren Holiday suspended, of course.

China go 4-2-3-1, and should play defensively ‚Äì Wang Shanshan has some pace up front, though, and could cause USA some problems on the counter.

Jim Harper has emailed!

I was quite surprised The Guardian didn‚Äôt have live coverage of Germany/France. You missed a hell of a game!

Yeah, it was great, wasn‚Äôt it? So sorry for France ‚Äì and Lavogez in particular. When she missed that final PK, she had tears in her eyes, and just grabbed Jessica Houara‚Äôs jersey with her teeth. It was really emotional.
Megan Rapinoe from earlier: she wants USA to ‚Äúdo the work‚Äù.

USA haven‚Äôt been that good so far this tournament, have they? Ponderous against Australia, lacking against Sweden, unconvincing against Nigeria, workmanlike against Colombia. But they‚Äôve never failed to reach the last four in World Cups, and they should prevail today. But a bit more flair and imagination wouldn‚Äôt go amiss.

Ariane Hingst in the Fox studio wonders whether USA are missing a trick by not selecting Wambach. China, Kelly Smith says, are going to play narrow at the back, so USA will have to go wide ‚Äì and they might require Wambach in the air.

A loss against China would be ‚Äúan absolute failure,‚Äù says Alexi Lalas.
Hingst says China are ‚Äúsolid on defence‚Äù, and feels Wang Lisi, breaking from midfield, is one to watch. And head coach Hao Wei is back for China after serving a one-match suspension.

Here‚Äôs Jill Ellis reflecting on the changes to the USA lineup: ‚ÄúI think Amy gives the ability to hold the ball up. Kelley loves to get forward, and I think she‚Äôll do a great job. Mo will play a bit more of a defensive role, but she‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù
Some pictures from Ottawa:
Amy Rodriguez, aka A-Rod, has played just 32 minutes at this tournament. Can she come in and do the biz?

Here‚Äôs Jon Pollak:

After watching the best match of the tournament... USA could actually beat the Germans. If, and it‚Äôs a big if, they up their game.

First things first, Jon! Let‚Äôs not get ahead of ourselves. Any China fans out there? Email me! I‚Äôd love to hear from you.

Ariane Hingst says of USA: ‚ÄúThey are better, stronger ‚Äì and they‚Äôll be playing Germany.‚Äù Lalas says USA have the best defence of the tournament, and Kelly Smith feels width is the key. Kick off is 13 minutes away ‚Äì we‚Äôre almost ready!

Paul LaMourie has some tactical advice:

Regarding Gaetane Thiney‚Äôs ET miss in Germany v France, to paraphrase Abby Wambach ‚Äúon grass I think that ball goes in‚Äù ‚Äì always more difficult to get on the end of a low cross with pace the way the ball moves on turf.

With Wambach not starting so long as Team USA plays their crosses from out wide on the ground, they‚Äôll be OK. Get to the byline, then cut the ball back to a trailer so the path of the pass isn‚Äôt parallel to the two lines of Chinese defenders that are sure to be bunkered in. Square balls into the middle will be too easy to cut out and clear.

Not much said about Klingenberg ‚Äì her overlaps have been impressive, and she‚Äôs very technical and therefore impactful when she adds to the attack out wide. Also able to play in tight spaces when she or a teammate wins possession and they play out of the back instead of booting it long.

The players are on the pitch. We‚Äôre listening to an announcement about fair play ‚Äì in English and French, of course. China look relaxed! They‚Äôre in red. USA are in white tracksuit tops, which I assume are covering blue shirts. Blue? Time for the anthems!
An observation: Julie Johnston has painted her nails in the colors of the national flag. U-S-A! U-S-A! Actually, Johnston has had a terrific tournament ‚Äì she‚Äôs a really top defender.
USA are in white! Forgive my earlier idiocy.
Carli Lloyd wins her 200th international cap. She‚Äôs the 10th USA player to reach that milestone. Wu, the China captain, wins the toss. It‚Äôs a full house here ‚Äì 24,000 fans or so.

2 min: USA kick off, and immeditely look long. It‚Äôs Wang‚Äôs ball. Tony DiCicco on commentary wants USA to start quickly ‚Äì and that‚Äôs a clear chance! Amy Rodriguez! Wu left it, and Rodriguez was clean through, but she tried to hit it with the outside of her left foot, and got it horribly wrong. Miles wide! That was a golden chance ‚Äì inside two minutes.

3 min: Nervy start by China, and that was a basic error in defence. Rodriguez had so much time, and she really was all alone in front of Wang, but it looked like she just had a brain freeze. Maybe she thought she was more comfortable in taking it with her left, but the natural angle was to hit it with her right, and she tried to bend it with the outside of her left. Big chance!
5 min: USA seeing lots of the ball early on, and Morgan has a try from distance, left footed. But Wang moves her feet well, and it‚Äôs an easy stop.
6 min: Better from China ‚Äì that‚Äôs a good pass for Wang Shanshan, but USA defend it well. USA on top.

8 min: USA have found acres of space in front of the Chinese back four, and that‚Äôs a decent effort from O‚ÄôHara, following some nimble work from Rodriguez out wide. Wang sees it over the top, though, and there‚Äôs no danger.

9 min: 63% of the possession so far from USA. Kyle Brown makes a perceptive point:

China doesn‚Äôt look as solid as advertised thus far.

Quite so! There really is a lot of space for USA.
11 min: Wang Shanshan and Han combine well down the left, and then Wang Lisi has a blast from distance. It‚Äôs blocked by Morgan Brian.
12 min: USA tried to attack down the left with Morgan, and there were nine Chinese players within about 10 yards of their own penalty box. Corner now for China ‚Ä¶

13 min: Wang Lisi slung it into the box, and Tan had a blast from distance, but it all came to naught. China not really clicking as an attacking force, but they‚Äôve settled after an inauspicious start.

14 min: Much better defending from China: Liu did well to shepherd the ball out of play as O‚ÄôHara went down the right. But Wang Shanshan is so isolated up front.

Here‚Äôs Charlie Dunn:

Big USA fan here. On a bus to NYC so my experience of the game is completely in your hands, Tim! Make sure to mention every time the ball spins weirdly on the turf to satisfy Wambach! Oh, and when Kelly O‚ÄôHara gets the opening goal before the 30 minute mark, please mention that I called it!

16 min: Tan gives it away cheaply, and USA come again, but China again are very quick to close down. They really are narrow and tight in front of that back four ‚Äì that early Rodriguez chance notwithstanding.

18 min: That was a good example of China‚Äôs shortcomings in attack: Wang Shanshan did well to pinch in from Klingenberg, but there was no one to pass to! Everyone behind the ball. Then Han has a blast from range, and spanks it into orbit.
20 min: Nice feet from Wang Lisi ‚Äì she‚Äôs impressed so far. Han tries to go down the left, but that‚Äôs solid defending from Kelley O‚ÄôHara, not for the first time.

21 min: Chance! It fell to Morgan after a nice layoff from Carli Lloyd, but Morgan couldn‚Äôt get any power with her left foot, and Wang saves easily. And then O‚ÄôHara with a header just wide! Heath did so well down the left, crossed to the back post, and O‚ÄôHara just couldn‚Äôt direct it on goal. Well played.
22 min: Rodriguez offside when she didn‚Äôt need to be: had she held her run, she‚Äôd have been in there. USA pressing here.

23 min: O‚ÄôHara has shown so much spunk down this right-hand side ‚Äì in defence and attack. And there she is again, trying to get on the end of Heath‚Äôs cross! Just wouldn‚Äôt fall for her, but this is good stuff from USA: they‚Äôve really picked up the tempo. China are rocking.

25 min: It‚Äôs anywhere will do at the moment for China ‚Äì Wang Shanshan is so isolated up front, it just keeps coming back. And that was a tense moment for her namesake Wang Fei ‚Äì she came for a cross and got nowhere near it, but Rodriguez just couldn‚Äôt profit. Free-kick for USA, though, now, in a dangerous position on the edge of the box on the right.

26 min: Heath with it ‚Ä¶ but well defended by China. And that‚Äôs off the line! Wang Fei came for another cross, and again didn‚Äôt get a clear contact. Krieger stabbed it goalwards, but it was hacked clear. China at sixes and sevens here!
29 min: That‚Äôs excellent defending from the left-back Liu Shanshan, heading clear when O‚ÄôHara looked ready to pounce ‚Äì ooh, and that‚Äôs a late one from Lou Jiahui on Johnston. No card, though.
30 min: Rolled in nicely to Rodriguez from the free-kick, but it rolls through to Wang Fei, and China can take a breather. They need it!
31 min: Oof, Rodriguez looked like she was in there down the right, but Zhao Rong did so well to come across and cover. Corner, though ‚Ä¶ and a free header for Johnston! Over the bar!
32 min: China have barely had a shot. They‚Äôve defended tenaciously, but the ball keeps coming back. They‚Äôre clinging on! Fortunately for them, O‚ÄôHara‚Äôs cross from the byline is behind.

33 min: Foul from Lloyd on Tan. Here‚Äôs Kyle Brown:

I think China has consumed about 6 of their 9 lives here.

Yep!

35 min: Better possession here from China ‚Äì Tan trying to make something happen from midfield. But they have so few players in advances positions, it‚Äôs difficult to get out. Then a bad giveaway from Lloyd! China attacked down the left, but Wang Lisu‚Äôs cross was just behind Wang Shanshan.
36 min: Change for China: Wang Shuang in for Lou Jiahui.

36 min: I like the look of Wang Fei, China‚Äôs goalkeeper: she looks like she has a bit of needle in her. In a good way! And she‚Äôs called upon here, beating away a long-range free kick from Carli Lloyd that dipped and swerved. Very well struck; well saved.
37 min: The technique from Lloyd there was textbook: the ball hardly wobbled. Now Lloyd looks to play in Rodriguez round the corner, but they‚Äôre not quite on the same wavelength.

38 min: Actually, China deserve great credit here: they had an awful opening five minutes or so, and looked all at sea, but they‚Äôve clung on, and shown desire and tenacity and courage, and they‚Äôre still at 0-0. They don‚Äôt look comfortable, but they‚Äôre still in this!

40 min: China have resolutely refused to go long to Wang Shanshan, but maybe they should: they‚Äôre all so deep, that a direct ball might relieve some pressure and get them on the front foot. There‚Äôs nowhere for them to go!
41 min: Lloyd looks as though she‚Äôs always prepared to start something: this we like. Then Krieger‚Äôs diagonal ball looks for Morgan, but it‚Äôs too high.

42 min: Surely it‚Äôs only a matter of time before USA score. USA go left, and then right, and there‚Äôs all kinds of movement, and now back to Johnston, and she looks for Rodriguez ‚Ä¶ but her touch is heavy, not for the first time, and that‚Äôs a goal kick.

43 min: Lovely turn by Heath, but China defend that well, and Wang Lisi, who‚Äôs been their best performer, carries it forward. Better from China ‚Äì that was much more confident passing ‚Äì but Wang Lisi‚Äôs shot doesn‚Äôt trouble Hope Solo.

blocks.title: Half-time: China 0-0 USA
blocks.body: 45 min: Lovely cushioned header from Carli Lloyd, but Morgan‚Äôs left foot shot is blocked by the redoubtable Wu. And that‚Äôs the half! USA have the edge, but it‚Äôs still 0-0. I‚Äôm not quite sure how, but it is!

Here‚Äôs Marc Howlett:

What tactical changes, if any, do you see US coach Jill Ellis making in the second half? Perhaps bringing on a Boxx to Boxx midfielder?

Maybe! But there‚Äôs very little criticism here of USA ‚Äì they‚Äôve played well, but just haven‚Äôt been able to score. That chance that fell to Rodriguez early on was golden: she should have tucked it away.

Colombia are playing Argentina in the quarter-finals of the Copa America ‚Äì and it‚Äôs tetchy! It‚Äôs 0-0 at half-time, and you can find out what happened in the first 45 with Nick Ames:

Related: Copa América quarter-final: Argentina v Colombia ‚Äì live!

Just watching that Rodriguez attempt again, and I misspoke: she tried to take it with her right, and bend it past the keeper. (Also, the bad mistake was from Li Dongna.)

Here‚Äôs the chance:

Daniel Stauss is not impressed by USA:

China‚Äôs defense looks far too comfortable in the face of this US ‚Ä¶ possession, not pressure. There‚Äôs an abysmal lack of interest from the US when it comes to the final ball in, or the incisive run to clear space, or really in anything much, and China seems more than fine with that.

The US looks completely flat. That was a boring first half. Credit to Julie Johnson, though, she‚Äôs been decent.
Our women‚Äôs soccer expert Caitlin Murray is in Ottawa:
USA are back on the pitch! And Abby Wambach gives a motivational speech, with plenty of fuckings thrown in for good measure.
46 min: OK, then, let‚Äôs go again! No changes at the half, and immediately China settle into their defensive shape.
47 min: Shot from Rodriguez. It‚Äôs speculative, and it‚Äôs well wide.
48 min: Lloyd goes on a sortie down the right, and that‚Äôs excellent support play from O‚ÄôHara. She‚Äôs crowded out, but it‚Äôs a USA corner ‚Äì and it‚Äôs a waste from Heath. China clear.

50 min: It‚Äôs going to be difficult for China to win this in their current set-up: they‚Äôre so deep, and so focused on defence, and they don‚Äôt have an out ball. Wang Shanshan has had to drop so deep to collect it, and the Chinese attackers are on top of their defenders. Some fine-tuning needed. Wu, the captain, trips Rodriguez. Yellow card.

blocks.title: GOAL! China 0-1 USA (Lloyd 51)
blocks.body: And there it is! Carli Lloyd!

51 min: All that hard defensive work China have put in, and they‚Äôre undone on a long ball! Johnston just tossed it into the penalty area, and Lloyd just got up higher than everyone else! Her header was solid, and accurate, and low, and maybe it skipped off the turf a little under Wang Fei‚Äôs body. But USA lead, and it‚Äôs the captain!
53 min: Now China have a problem. They have to score, otherwise they‚Äôre going home, but how do they do that without opening themselves up? Head coach Hao Wei has to earn his money here.
55 min: Corner to USA. And Wang Fei misses it again! She‚Äôs a good goalie, but she‚Äôs missed three punches on crosses today. Fortunately for her, China scramble it clear.
57 min: Change for Tan Ruyin out, Pang Fengyue in. Tan looks beat. USA playing with 10 ‚Äì Kelley O‚ÄôHara is bleeding from her nose.

58 min: A reminder that the winner here will play Germany on Tuesday in Montreal. China need a goal! They‚Äôre pressing a little higher up the pitch, but now here come USA the other way, with Morgan down the left. She‚Äôs crowded out.

60 min: China had a corner there, and they played it short, and Wu crossed it ‚Äì but only Wang Shanshan was in the box! Potty! Change for USA ‚Äì O‚ÄôHara out, Christen Press in. I think O‚ÄôHara got clattered by Wang Fei about five minutes ago, and couldn‚Äôt continue. But O‚ÄôHara should be proud: she‚Äôs played really well.
64 min: China are plenty young, so they shouldn‚Äôt tire. But that was a chance! Wang Shanshan‚Äôs header, and Wang Lisi just couldn‚Äôt get on the end of it.

65 min: For all the talk of them being a defensive team, China pass it very nicely: they‚Äôve got some technically accomplished players. They‚Äôve come out from their ultra-defensive shape now: there‚Äôll be more goals in this. That‚Äôs my hot take!
66 min: Rodriguez tries to pinch one from Wu in the right-back slot, but she can‚Äôt control it. Goal kick, and Wang Fei will send it long.

67 min: Julie Johnston has been immaculate here tonight, and she wins another clean header from Wang Shanshan. Now Wang Shuang tries to go through the middle, but it‚Äôs mopped up. Nothing doing for China so far.
69 min: China coming into this now! It‚Äôs a corner ‚Ä¶
70 min: ‚Ä¶ and Solo punches clear, somewhat nervously. It‚Äôs sent back in by Wang Shuang, but no danger.

71 min: They haven‚Äôt really created any clear openings, China, but they‚Äôre game, and Wu moves forward smoothly. China on the front foot here, but Liu‚Äôs pass is errant, and here come USA on the break. Morgan can‚Äôt keep it in, but this game has some nice ebb and flow.

73 min: My oh my, what a shot! So nearly 2-0: Ali Krieger hits the bar! It didn‚Äôt look as if anything was on, so she just had a dip with her left foot from outside the box, and it clanged back off the woodwork! (Does wood clang?) Great effort, and so unlucky. Final change for China. Tang replaces Han Peng.
75 min: USA look OK here: China haven‚Äôt really got round the sides and hurt them, and USA look the more likely scorers right now.
78 min: Great play from Morgan down the left, beating Wu with skill and pace, but her cross is just too long for Christen Press.

79 min: Urgency required from China, but they can‚Äôt quite get going. Ooh, here‚Äôs a chance, though: Sauerbrunn comes through the back of Wang Shanshan, and it‚Äôs a free kick about 30 yards from goal.

80 min: Wang Lisi tried a curler, but straight at Hope Solo. Incidentally, USA haven‚Äôt conceded a goal in the second half of games at this tournament. And they don‚Äôt look like they‚Äôre going to concede here, either.

81 min: Heather O‚ÄôReilly on for Alex Morgan: ‚ÄúShe is a workhorse ‚Äì and she‚Äôs so fast,‚Äù says Cat Whitehill on commentary. Nine minutes to hold it up, run around a bit, and generally make a nuisance of herself.
82 min: USA look comfortable here. China have to take a chance, no?
84 min: China go long into the box, looking for Wang Shanshan, but Solo claims easily.

85 min: Rodriguez gets clear down the left, but it breaks down again ‚Äì but then Press accepts the lose ball, and fires at goal. It‚Äôs blocked. Corner! And a final change: Abby Wambach for Amy Rodriguez.
86 min: And a chance for Christen Press! Low corner from Heath, dummied by Wambach, but Press fired over. Nicely worked.
87 min: China can‚Äôt get the ball. They look jaded.

88 min: Handball by Press. China need a goal, but they just haven‚Äôt functioned as an attacking force. Much endeavour, but little craft. Johnston steps in to take it from Wang Shuang. China going out with a whimper.
89 min: And a chance for Christen Press seal it! She beat two ‚Äì she went past Li easily in the box ‚Äì but her shot was off target. Shame: the approach play was nice.
90 min: Pang tries to force a corner, but Johnston sees it out for a goal kick.
90 min + 1: Three minutes of added time. Can China make one final chance?
90 min + 2: No. It‚Äôs just not happening for the Chinese. A minute left.

blocks.title: Full-time: China 0-1 USA
blocks.body: 90 min + 3: Pang fires from distance. It‚Äôs ambitious, and Solo fields with no drama. China just haven‚Äôt thrown enough players forward. And that‚Äôs it! USA go through!
Well, that was much easier than the score suggests. China just didn‚Äôt have enough. USA were comfortable. Next up: Germany!
Michael Phelps is happy:
Just looking back at that goal: Lloyd got up really well. It was a nothing ball in from Johnston, but Lloyd did brilliantly.

Here‚Äôs Jill Ellis:

‚ÄúI think it was a highly energised performance, and created a lot of opportunities, so yeah, we‚Äôre really pelased. I thought Amy Rodriguez was fantastic tonight, I just thought overall the team played very well. It‚Äôs time to play. It‚Äôs kind of what we said: let‚Äôs put the group stage behind us, and let‚Äôs do this.‚Äù

Well played China, but they didn‚Äôt really show anything in attack. Wang Shanshan and Wang Lisi looked positive, but they‚Äôre essentially a defensive team, and once Lloyd scored, China didn‚Äôt look like responding.

Caitlin Murray was at the game in Ottawa: here‚Äôs her game report:

Related: Women's World Cup quarter-final | USA 1-0 China
OK, we‚Äôre going to wrap this blog up. Well done to USA, and commiserations to China. Thanks for reading. Bye.

keyEvents.body:
Tim will be here shortly. In the meantime, here‚Äôs Caitlin Murray on why USA have to improve:

For a team that has advanced into the final eight and remains a favorite to win, the tone about the USA‚Äôs performances from pundits covering the team and from personnel affiliated with the program has become increasingly negative.

Former player Michelle Akers, who won the Golden Boot in 1991 when the USA won the Women‚Äôs World Cup, was especially blunt in her criticism after the USA‚Äôs 2-0 win over Colombia. Akers said of Ellis: ‚ÄúIf she is pleased with the way we played tonight, then what the hell is she doing coaching our US team?‚Äù

Related: USA face China for a last-four spot ‚Äì and if they don't improve, they're going home

keyEvents.title: Germany into semi-finals
keyEvents.body: Germany have just beaten France in Montreal, on penalty kicks, in the most heartbreaking fashion. Poor Claire Lavogez ‚Äì she took the final kick, Nadine Angerer saved, and the look on Lavogez‚Äôs face. So sad! Great game, that was: 1-1 after extra time, but France didn‚Äôt deserve to go out.

keyEvents.title: Half-time: China 0-0 USA
keyEvents.body: 45 min: Lovely cushioned header from Carli Lloyd, but Morgan‚Äôs left foot shot is blocked by the redoubtable Wu. And that‚Äôs the half! USA have the edge, but it‚Äôs still 0-0. I‚Äôm not quite sure how, but it is!

keyEvents.title: GOAL! China 0-1 USA (Lloyd 51)
keyEvents.body: And there it is! Carli Lloyd!

keyEvents.title: Full-time: China 0-1 USA
keyEvents.body: 90 min + 3: Pang fires from distance. It‚Äôs ambitious, and Solo fields with no drama. China just haven‚Äôt thrown enough players forward. And that‚Äôs it! USA go through!

headerImage.caption: USA and China battle in Ottawa. Photograph: Marc DesRosiers/USA Today Sports
headerImage.altText: USA and China battle in Ottawa.
headerImage.cleanCaption: USA and China battle in Ottawa.

snap.title: Women's World Cup: USA beat China 1-0 to reach semi-finals ‚Äì as it happened

image.altText: USA and China battle in Ottawa.

cards.title: Australia sport / Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders
cards.rawTitle: Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders

item.title: Shaun Johnson inspires Warriors in big win against Raiders
item.trailText: Star halfback Shaun Johnson again provided the spark as the Warriors consolidated their position in the top eight with a 30-8 win over Canberra in Auckland.
item.body:
Star halfback Shaun Johnson again provided the spark as the Warriors consolidated their position in the top eight with a 30-8 win over Canberra in Auckland.

It was Johnson, with his speed and step, who scored the try that gave the Warriors breathing space early in the second half of Saturday‚Äôs clash.

He then set up Tuimoala Lolohea for the winger‚Äôs second touchdown with a kick into the in-goal.

Winger Manu Vatuvei added the icing with four minutes to go by pulling in a lobbed pass from opposition halfback Sam Williams for his 11th try of the season.

It was also Vatuvei‚Äôs 14th try in his past seven matches against Canberra.

The win is the Warriors‚Äô fifth in a row over the Raiders, who remain in the bottom half of the table ahead of a bye for both teams.

The home side dominated possession and produced plenty of offloads as they forced the Raiders to make more than 400 tackles for the second weekend in a row.

They followed-up their victory over Gold Coast with another controlled start.

They got their reward in the 11th minute when second-rower Bodene Thompson marked his 100th NRL match by busting the line to dot down.

Canberra had been starved of good field position but made their first incursion into the Warriors‚Äô 20-metre zone tell.

Second-rower Sia Solioala‚Äôs inside ball sent fullback Jack Wighton over in the 18th minute.

Jarrod Croker landed the conversion and then nudged the visitors ahead with a penalty.

The Warriors regained the lead on the half-hour, blockbusting centre Konrad Hurrell taking on three defenders before offloading to Lolohea to score.

Johnson added the extras, then a penalty after the half-time hooter, for a 14-8 lead.

The Raiders‚Äô defeat was compounded by injury, with winger Jordan Rapana limping off before half-time.

Former Newcastle centre Joseph Leilua, signed earlier in June, came off the bench to make his Raiders debut.

displayImages.altText: Bodene Thompson scores a try despite the attentions of Edrick Lee during the match between the New Zealand Warriors and the Canberra Raiders at Mt Smart Stadium on Saturday.

snap.title: Shaun Johnson sparks Warriors in victory over Raiders

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / Tom Daley leads GB divers in search of Rio 2016 Olympic spots
cards.rawTitle: Tom Daley leads GB divers in search of Rio 2016 Olympic spots

item.title: Tom Daley leads GB divers in search of Rio 2016 Olympic spots
item.trailText: Tom Daley said grabbing Olympic diving spots at the world championships was his main aim
item.standFirst:
‚Ä¢ Tom Daley says grabbing Olympic spots at swimming worlds is main aim
‚Ä¢ Commonwealth Games champion Jack Laugher also in Great Britain squad
item.body:
Tom Daley will lead a nine-strong Great Britain diving team into swimming‚Äôs world championships in Kazan next month.

Daley, who won bronze at London 2012, is joined by his fellow Commonwealth Games champion Jack Laugher in a strong team who will aim to earn qualification places for the Rio 2016 Olympics.

Daley said: ‚ÄúCompeting at the world championships a year out from Rio is a key moment for all of the British divers. We‚Äôll be looking to grab those Olympic spots for Great Britain. That‚Äôs our main aim at this competition.

‚ÄúI love competing and I love facing up to the best in the world. Most of the team has been on the world series circuit so we‚Äôve been competing at a high level for most of the season but I think everyone will up their game at the worlds. I can‚Äôt wait to get out there. Winning medals earlier in the season gives me confidence going into Kazan.‚Äù

Six British divers are ranked in the world top 12 after this year‚Äôs diving world series.

The world series overall winner, Tonia Couch, will compete individually and also with partner Sarah Barrow in the 10m platform synchro.

The Commonwealth champions Rebecca Gallantree and Alicia Blagg will compete in the 3m springboard and 3m synchro. Matty Lee and James Denny will make their world championship debuts.

GB diving team

For world championships in Kazan, Russia (24 July-2 Aug): Tom Daley (Dive London), James Denny, Jack Laugher, Matty Lee, Chris Mears (all City of Leeds), Sarah Barrow, Tonia Couch (both Plymouth Diving), Alicia Blagg, Rebecca Gallantree (both City of Leeds).

cards.title: Sailing / Ben Ainslie says Team New Zealand will still be an America‚Äôs Cup force
cards.rawTitle: Ben Ainslie says Team New Zealand will still be an America‚Äôs Cup force

item.title: Ben Ainslie says Team New Zealand will still be an America‚Äôs Cup force
item.trailText: Ben Ainslie is confident that rivals Team New Zealand will be strong challengers at the 2017 America‚Äôs Cup despite the team‚Äôs criticisms of the decision to reduce the boat size for the competition
item.standFirst:
‚Ä¢ Team New Zealand had criticised boat size reduction
‚Ä¢ Briton‚Äôs team renamed Land Rover BAR in new commercial deal
item.body:
Ben Ainslie is confident that rivals Team New Zealand will be strong challengers at the 2017 America‚Äôs Cup despite the team being highly critical of the controversial decision to reduce the boat size for the competition.

Earlier this year plans were approved to change boats from 62ft (AC62) catamarans to AC45s in the 45ft to 50ft range for the 2017 competition in Bermuda. The decision resulted in the Italian team Luna Rossa withdrawing from the America‚Äôs Cup and Team New Zealand‚Äôs chief executive accused the remaining four crews of ‚Äúself-serving manoeuvring‚Äù.

Ainslie, who won the 2013 America‚Äôs Cup in remarkable circumstances against the New Zealanders with Team Oracle USA, is fronting a new British team for the 2017 competition and on Wednesday announced a new partnership with Land Rover. Ainslie‚Äôs team was renamed Land Rover BAR at their new multimillion pound base in Portsmouth that became operational this week.

Related: Luna Rossa pull out of America‚Äôs Cup in protest over reduced boat size

Of the row regarding boat size for 2017, Ainslie said: ‚ÄúIt was regrettable that Luna Rossa decided to withdraw from the cup ‚Äì Team New Zealand have been having a pretty tumultuous time of late and I think there is a lot more going on within that team other than just the issues around the class rule.

‚ÄúNow we have teams committed to moving forward in this exciting new class of boat, sharing a common goal. Team New Zealand, like ourselves, are heavily reliant on commercial funding. I‚Äôll be hugely surprised that as a commercial team they could suddenly decide to not compete. I‚Äôm confident they will be there and be a strong challenger like they have been in the past.

‚ÄúWe supported the shift to smaller boats for two reasons. Firstly, the longer-term vision from all the teams was to have continuity in the circuit, that we could collectively design a boat for the next America‚Äôs Cup and use the same one beyond. The other side was to reduce the costs; this new class of boat is containerised so the logistics of getting it around the world are more achievable.‚Äù

Land Rover, the British automotive manufacturer, becomes a central part of Ainslie‚Äôs technical innovation group. It is the latest move by the four-times Olympic sailing champion to cement links with the motor industry, having already recruited Adrian Newey ‚Äì Formula One‚Äôs most decorated designer ‚Äì and Martin Whitmarsh, the former McLaren team principal who became BAR‚Äôs chief executive in March.

Next month the America‚Äôs Cup World Series event takes place in Portsmouth, a qualification race for the 35th America‚Äôs Cup in Bermuda. More than 90,000 tickets have already been sold for the four days.

displayImages.caption: Ben Ainslie's team supported the shift to smaller boats for the America's Cup. Photograph: Ian Roman/PA
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ben Ainslie's team supported the shift to smaller boats for the America's Cup. Photograph: Ian Roman/PA

snap.title: Ben Ainslie says Team New Zealand will still be an America‚Äôs Cup force
